title: How to start writing creative things - Quora

response.answer_text: I think the harder question is why rather than how. How: you sit down and write. If you don’t have any ideas, brainstorm, or look at some of the techniques suggested all over Quora. How do I come up with ideas to write about? I am sitting here, staring at the wall. No ideas are coming. Don’t forget to look at the suggested questions related to the above question. They’re on the right side of your screen. There are loads of them that will help you. If you have trouble finding your ‘voice’ or you’re not sure how to turn an idea into a story, there are loads of books about this. One that I like to suggest is: Amazon.com: Plot Versus Character: A Balanced Approach to Writing Great Fiction (0035313650352): Jeff Gerke: Books There’s also: Amazon.com: Story: Style, Structure, Substance, and the Principles of Screenwriting eBook: Robert McKee: Kindle Store But some people find that one too complicated. I think a beginner can do fine with it if they’re a careful reader and don’t insist on ‘getting’ all the information into their heads the first time they read it. It’s best to read some, write some, read some more … it’s a great book to reread because you’ll get something new out of it each time you make progress with your writing craft. But maybe you need this Quora thread for the how: I want to write a novel, but don't have an appealing story idea, skill as a writer, free time, tenacity, imagination, or observational skill needed to write a good novel. What should I do? None of this advice will make a bit of difference, though, unless you figure out why you want to write. Is it for fun? Do you want to develop a side income stream? Do you have things you want to say to the world? Are you a masochist? (The last comment is meant to be funny. I feel like a masochist sometimes because of my compulsion to write.) Until you have a purpose, whether it’s self-entertainment, therapy, you want to work toward becoming a professionally published author, or some other reason, it’s going to be hard to direct your efforts. It’s also going to be hard to give you specific advice that will be useful for you. I hope this helps!

If you mean by “creative” the same thing I mean by “creative,” you’ve already started, merely by creating that one sentence question? You could have asked it in dozens of different ways, or not ask it at all, but you created it. Some people think that fiction is synonymous with “creative,” but they’re only looking at the writer’s skill with words. Yes, flowery, evocative words can make some fine writing, but that’s not all there is to creativity in writing. Any time you write something that’s never been written before, you’re creating. In fact, the only writing I can think of that’s not “creative” is plagiarism. In fiction, for example, you are being creative when you choose which scenes to write and which to omit. But you do the same thing in writing non-fiction. If you’re writing, say, about World War II, which battles do you choose to write about? What non-battle events do you describe? And how many details of each do you write, and which do you omit. Those are all “creative things.” No two accounts of World War II will be the same. Each will be a “creative thing.” Then, too, it’s creative to decide on the order of things in you writing. Where does the story of a romance begin? Where does the story of World War II begin? Do you choose chronological order in your writing, or do you go back and forth in time? If two events take place concurrently, which do you place first in your writing? Or perhaps you switch back and forth with a little of one alternating with a bit of the other? In other words, any time you write anything that’s not merely copying someone else’s words, you writing a “creative thing.” So, just stop worrying about creativity and start writing. Good luck! Weinberg on Writing: The Fieldstone Method

You ask three questions, how do I start to write? This is easy, start with a prompt. Write one sentence with your character entering a place. Write one sentence where the character confronts a villian. Write dialogue between them. Write one sentence after the protagonist or villian leaves, explaining what has changed. Keep going, write as much as you can. You ask a second question, how do I write? This should be without lifting your fingers from the keypad or paper or using delete. The edit, edit, edit. You ask a third question, how do I write creatively? This can be with imagination or by creating something new. Newness can only be evaluated by knowing what is old and looking for gaps. Newness can be from a different perspective or using a different style or technique. Newness can invent style, knowledge, news, science, techology, insight, argumentation, process, place or character. Newness can be a combination of things. Writing with imagination may be that you start with a set of facts, then immerse yourself in the dream of what you create. This is usually associated with fiction or poetry or creative nonfiction, allowing a reader to walk with you through a time, place, emotionally imbued experience. The more a reader experiences the more creatively you have written. So notice sensory experiences and include them. Also notice your emotions, and how emotion is seen in others.

I get asked this question a lot. And my answer is always: just start. Make a teeny, tiny goal that’s so small, its harder to skip it than it is to just do it. My go-to is ten minutes. Write something creative for ten minutes a day, every single day. Get a calendar and give yourself a big X or a star sticker for every day that you meet your goal. A visual reminder of your chain of writing days will give you a boost to keep going. If you’re not sure what you want to write, here are some ideas. Pick up a book and write the first paragraph of it, just to get your fingers moving, then keep going in your own words.Search through Google Images until you find a picture that sparks a story idea.Write fan fiction.Make a list of characters you want to write about.Make a list of situations your characters might get themselves into.Pick one thing from each list, a character and a situation, and then write that story.Get a book of writing prompts and just make your way through it.Give yourself absolute permission to write total crap. Perfectionism is the death of creativity.

It isn’t how you start writing creative things, it’s how do you find inspiration to write creative things. As long as you have the inspiration. you can write a creative sentence or paragraph relatively easily. There are many ways to find inspiration. One example is to just write even though you have no idea what to write. Another way is to Google it. There are many great tutorials on how to write inspiration. This next suggestion may sound crazy, but it can work. If you’re like me and you sometimes get very creative ideas at the most random moments, either talk to whoever brings these ideas like this: “Look, can you please bring me these ideas when I’m actually writing or am in the correct location and condition to write?” Another way, my preferred way, is to simply keep thinking of the idea and don’t stop until you can write it down.

Have you ever watched a movie or a TV show and realized that you didn’t like the story because it was too predictable, or it didn’t flow, or else something was left hanging that shouldn’t have been included? Or have you ever liked a series and you’d love to see an episode with certain challenges and elements in it? That can get you into fanfiction which is a great way for some to start because you can work on story, using established characters, in an established ‘reality’ and you can run right into it. You can take a ‘what if?’ and immediately get into writing about it if you use established characters. Later, you can learn to build up the world, build up your own characters and have tremendous fun creating everything and sharing more of your imagination, but from what I understand about fan fiction, it’s a great head start on the important aspect of story telling.

Carry a notebook everywhere. There is no pressure because no one will see it. Observe, draw, write down dialogue bits, frame scenes that are unusual. I keep a file of “happy phrases” and title ideas. Read dead writers’ noteBooks. Read Hemingway’s A Moveable Feast, it has many many good tips about his process learning to write. Use a pencil. You will feel less pressure because it does not feel permanent. Write with fire, that is the most important thing.

A good process regarding writing creatively is to brainstorm to first come up with an idea, a theme or a story. You can also just start to write and not stop for 3 minute stretches and then put your fragments/cut ups up on a wall and look for a theme emerging. Some say that you should just write and avoid the urge to stop and edit as you go along. This is a kind of automatic writing. Another technique is to sign post with section/chapter headings before you start writing which gives you a map for your story. Train your brain to come up with ideas. Visualise what you think into pictures or short film clips in your brain and then write them down. Hope this helps. Just start writing and do so everyday.

If you want to write any creative things than at first think about it. Read about it and design it in your mind. Start your writing with making an beautiful intro for your writing. Then describe it with pretty sentences. And at last write a conclusion.

Creativity is a developed skill. You should boost your writing skills… by reading, listening, watching. You can read some books that you have never heard about, you can watch films of genres that you have never been interested in, you can attend some events, or just walking around the city. Every new experience can boost your creativity!
